curam.util.exception

Class LocalisableString

  • java.lang.Object
    • curam.util.exception.LocalisableString

  • public class LocalisableString
extends java.lang.Object
    LocalisableString is commonly used in Curam applications to produce a string which can be localized by the client. This is similar in construction and use to the AppException class - but a LocalisableString cannot be thrown.

    LocalisableString objects have message text associated with them. Rather than specifying the text directly when you instantiate the class, a reference to an entry in a message catalog is used. The reference is a constant value generated by Curam based on message catalog definitions in a ".xml" file. Message Catalogs allow messages to be localized. The message text can also have "placeholders" associated with it, replaced at runtime with arguments that you add to the exception.

    Placeholders can appear anywhere in the message text and are introduced by a percent character e.g.: "This is the text of message number %1n"

    Placeholders are of the form: `%nc`, where n is a number (of 1 or more digits), and c is a single character denoting the argument type as follows:

    • s - string
    • n - numeric
    • d - date
    • t - time
    • z - date/time
    • c - code item
    The `'\'` character can be used as an escape character anywhere in the message text, and must be used whenever the message text needs to contain a percent sign `'\%'`, or a backslash `'\\'`.

    The code item is treated separately from a string to allow for localization in the client. Code Items are returned in the text of an exception as <TableName>:<Code>. This ensures that the client can present the associated description in the correct language for the user.

    In your code, you provide arguments to replace placeholders with the "arg" methods of LocalisableString. Here's an example: LocalisableString ls = new LocalisableString(MY_CATALOG.MYMESSAGE); ls.arg("some text"); ls.arg(25); Because the "arg" methods return a reference to the LocalisableString, the above is equivalent to the following shorthand: new LocalisableString(MY_CATALOG.MYMESSAGE).arg("some text") .arg(25); The order in which you add arguments determines which placeholders they replace -- the first argument replaces the placeholder with number 1, the second replaces number 2, and so on. This means that localized versions of messages can have placeholders which do not appear in the same order as the non-localized ones.

    It should be noted that if a string is provided as an argument where a code table is specified then the string will be output. If a code table is used as an argument where a string is specified then the code table will be output.

    See Also:
    AppException

      • getArguments

        public java.util.ArrayList getArguments()
        Return the ArrayList list of arguments for the localisable string.
        Returns:
        ArrayList of the arguments that have been added to the message, in the order they have been added. If no args have been added the ArrayList will have a size of zero.

      • toString

        public java.lang.String toString()
        Get the extended message text which includes the catalog name, entry number and the text associated with that exception in the default server locale.
        Overrides:
        toString in class java.lang.Object
        Returns:
        The extended message text. If the text associated with the localisable string exceeds 4K (4096 bytes) it is truncated to this size.

      • toClientFormattedText

        public java.lang.String toClientFormattedText()
        Convert to a formatted string so that this can be returned to a Curam client in the specified locale.
        Returns:
        A string in the format expected by a client. output from the method is a contract with the client infrastructure method curam.util.client.message.ClientMessageBuilder.formatArgument().

      • getMessage

        public java.lang.String getMessage()
        Get the text associated with the exception in the default server locale. The basic text is loaded from a Message Catalog, and any placeholders in the text are replaced with arguments attached to the AppException instance. Substitution of the placeholders is performed as per the LocalisableString class description.
        Returns:
        String which has the placeholders updated with the actual arguments. If the string exceeds 4K (4096 bytes) it is truncated to this size.

      • getMessage

        public java.lang.String getMessage(java.lang.String locale)
        Get the text associated with the exception in the specified locale. The basic text is loaded from a Message Catalog, and any placeholders in the text are replaced with arguments attached to the AppException instance. Substitution of the placeholders is performed as per the LocalisableString class description.
        Parameters:
        locale - The specified locale.
        Returns:
        String which has the placeholders updated with the actual arguments. If the string exceeds 4K (4096 bytes) it is truncated to this size.

      • getMessage

        public java.lang.String getMessage(java.util.Locale locale)

Substitution of the placeholders is performed as per the LocalisableString class description.
